transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
Hey, everybody.
My name is Stan Walker.
I'm an engineer at Harris Walk.
This is a workshop about Key Space,
which is a protocol for your intern
in the encryption using Ethereum and IPSS.
[INAUDIBLE]
Before I get started, I wanted to give a bit of a prologue
for putting this piece of technology in a larger context
of what I see of emerging technologies.
So the inspiration for Key Space first
came to me about a year ago when I was listening to a podcast
by Arthur Falls called The Third Web.
He was interviewing a developer named Dominic Tar,
who's the-- who developed a distributed social media
network called Secure Scout, but kind of you
are familiar with that.
But the thing I really liked in the interview
was he talked about this concept called Cypress Space.
So Cypress Space is what Key Space is
as kind of an emerging style of application development
on the web that has a kind of a proper abstraction
between the networking layer and the application layer.
And that proper abstraction is enabled for the first time,
really, by use of different cryptographic primitives.
I think that having your application logic divorced
from your networking logic looks kind of like a graph
you can kind of specify what your application needs,
but you don't have to worry about how it gets to you.
So I think some more concrete examples
of what Cypress Space is and how this development methodology
is going to play out in the future.
It's going to be made clear in some later examples.
But just to have that context issue
is you kind of watch this presentation.
So this is the agenda.
We're going to start out on a high level
and just answer what is through space,
so why was it built and what are its core infinites.
Then we're going to zoom in a little bit more
with the in-depth technical description.
So there's kind of three main stages
in the user life cycle within the protocol.
We're going to have a work through each of those.
After that is the fun part.
We have an interactive example.
So there's kind of a demo dot that you all can load up
on either your desktop or your phone.
And we can kind of do some peer-to-peer encrypted group
messaging amongst each other.
And then after that, we'll have some time for questions
or exploration to see what we can do with this kind of protocol.
So first definitions.
What is Key Space?
I think the simplest way to sum it up
is that Key Space is a trustless, open PGP implementation
built on top of Ethereum's existing cryptographic
key tooling.
So some obvious questions come up from this definition.
First of all, for those unfamiliar
with cryptographic protocols, what is open PGP?
And secondly, why we need open PGP on Ethereum?
So PGP stands for free and privacy.
It's an encryption program that provides cryptographic privacy
and authentication for data communication.
PGP is used for signing and scripting and decrypting text,
emails, files, directories, and whole disk partitions
and to increase the security of email communication.
So that's just the definition of what it could be.
So PGP, a little background.
It was developed by a cryptographer named Phil Zenerin
in the '90s.
It was first developed as enterprise software.
It was first developed as enterprise software in 1991,
around '97, Phil decided that this would only work
if it was open source.
So he started the open PGP initiative.
Then around 2014 is when elliptic cryptography
was added to the protocol spec, which
is much wider weight than the older
forms of encryption that the protocol used, like RSA.
This kind of lighter footprint allowed
it to be more realistically used in the browser.
So open PGP.js was added about the same time
kind of opening the door for end-to-end encryption,
screen-to-screen encryption.
So there's no-- it's kind of the standard of encryption
that we would like to have today, which is used by Telegram
or Signal or other things like that.
So why do we need to bring PGP on Ethereum?
So a little background.
This came to be because of specific kind of
existing inside AirSwap pad.
So in kind of the history of like,
DEX development, the first popular DEX is like Ether Delta.
All the information was held on chain,
like in the smart contracts.
So both order posting, order matching,
and order of settlement all happened on chain.
Kind of second generation DEXs had some improvements
on this to save gas.
So on verticals like AirSwap, 0x,
i.x, DEX is hydro-protocol, and de-idases,
and unit orders all kind of used a similar approach
for gas saving where an order is signed off-chain.
It's posted somewhere, matched off-chain,
and then settled on-chain.
So on AirSwap in particular, the way
that the protocol works is that order posting happens
period of year, so makers send orders directly to takers.
Matching happens when the taker decides
that they want to fill the order,
and then the actual settlement happens
when the order is filled on chain.
But since all of this is being moved off-chain into messaging,
that messaging has to happen somewhere.
So there's a possible information asymmetry that arises,
because for example, if AirSwap is hosting the messaging platform,
then we have a global view into all the messaging
that's happening that could potentially
give us an unfair advantage of a scene
of trade that's going to happen before it happens,
or a TC style interaction, we can see people negotiating
a trade-implant text.
So you eliminate this unfair angle,
or this unfair view, leading encryption.
So if all messages between makers and takers
are encrypted, then they're the only ones who are able to see it.
And there isn't any kind of global view
to exploit from the angle of being a more technical party,
or having a global access to the system.
So we need both encryption for that reason,
and then we need authentication to basically tie the messages
that are created to a particular theory
address so that if somebody is being abusive in the messages
that they send, for example, trying to de-doss the network,
we can say, OK, these messages are cryptographically verifiable,
is having come from this address.
We're going to disable--
that address can't send messages anymore,
and then we can see if assets transfer between that address
and another address, we can basically figure out
who's using the network, or have some standard where
we can have economic incentives for behaving correctly.
So obviously, in my authentication,
I just need a signature verification of messages.
So there's a lot of different cryptographic protocols
that you can use for authentication and encryption
of messaging, but PGT seemed like the right choice
for multiple reasons.
One of the main ones is that it's the right age.
And what I mean by that is that it's been around long enough
that it's fairly safe.
It is very robust.
It's used all over the world.
And it's been around long enough that it has
a great tooling associated with it, which helps
on the developer lived it into my hair,
perfectly like this.
But then it's also simultaneously new enough
that it uses cryptographic algorithms,
like elliptic hermitography, which
is way enough to use in the browser without negatively
impacting the user experience.
OK.
So that's kind of like the high level view of why we needed
to implement this trustless version of PGP on Ethereum.
So we're going to zoom in a little bit
and talk about the specific implementation
and how it looks and feels for user.
So the first step in that is a key generation in recovery.
So what this means is that we're trying
to deterministically generate that PGP key pair
from Ethereum key pairs, such that we
can verify that this Ethereum address generated this PGP key.
And that, if the PGP key is lost for whatever reason,
we tend to regenerate it as long as you have control
of the wallet.
So kind of a practical example of this
is if I have my ledger and I generate my keys on one computer
and I use those keys to read my encrypted messages,
I can then terminate that session
where I felt that information, plug my ledger
into another computer, regenerate my PGP keys,
and use them to decrypt the same messages.
So it's kind of a stateless in a way, and it's deterministic.
And so that's just kind of one of the properties
we wanted to have in the system.
The next step after keys are generated
is a key distribution and lookup.
So if I want to send a encrypted message to you
by knowing you're a Ethereum address,
I have to have some way to look up that Ethereum address
and find your PGP key.
And I need to be able to cryptographically verify
that that is indeed your PGP key,
which I can then use that public key
to your encrypted message and send it to.
So there needs to be some sort of directory, basically.
The initial implementation of this actually for us
was a smart contract.
So you basically stored your PGP key on IPFS,
took the IPFS hash of that key and sorted the smart contract.
And then when I wanted to find the key associated
with your address, I would just look it up
in the smart contract.
Pretty soon though, we discovered that there
is a whole swath of users who wanted to basically
try an application without paying gas upfront.
As soon as you have to pay for a transaction,
they weren't as interested in using that application.
So there is another alternative way
of storing these keys where instead of storing a contract,
you sign it so that you can verify it as yours.
And then the signature together with the key
can just be stored in any database.
And since that signature always exists next with it,
you can just pull it and look it up.
It doesn't have the same guarantees
available to you as a smart contract.
So currently that database is hosted by Riswap.
And if the pair swap went away,
then that database wouldn't be hosted.
But for those users, they would just
have to regenerate their keys and they
could begin using the system again.
So there's different options of based
on the longevity, the dependability that you need.
And the level of trustlessness that you desire,
you can pay more for that or have more of a low investment
also reactive.
So the thread stuff in this is passive authentication
and privacy.
So after everything's set up, basically,
keys are generated, they're distributed,
and they can be looked up.
Then we can use them at the application level
without really having to understand anything
about the underlying cryptography.
So just all messages between peers
are have the simultaneous guarantee of if you receive
a message, you know for sure that the Ethereum address that
sent you that message is who they claim to be.
And when you send a message that nobody other than the Ethereum
address that you intend to read it will read it.
So that's kind of like high level.
Oops, I got out of the query.
So zooming in on a key generation,
so there's actually some--
we're not the first people to kind of come up
against some of these problems.
And a lot of the many of the cryptographic libraries
that wallets, like Metamask, for example,
depend on provide methods of deriving secondary keys
from primary keys.
But unfortunately, there isn't an RPC spec
for kind of exposing these methods to the end user and a DAP.
So the way that we get around that
is a key generation happens by taking the passphrase, which
is just the plain text word or a set of words, and then
assigning it, and then using that hex string that's generated
as kind of the encryption key for-- that encrypts your private
PGP key, basically.
So open PGP.js, when you generate a new key pair,
you have the option to pass in a passphrase.
That's kind of the encryption password.
So that signed message becomes the encryption password
for your key pair, basically.
So that's kind of a low level of how those two are associated.
And then once that key is created,
IPFS provides kind of cheap reliable storage.
So the way that works for us is that we store the IPFS--
we store the key pair in IPFS in basically a redundant set
of nodes, using a pin set.
So they go from inferior to pinata to our own IPFS node
to Cloudfire and some others.
So we kind of use that pin set to replicate across all
those nodes.
So that kind of makes these key pairs reliably available
without having to store them on a smart contract, basically.
So key distribution.
So this is kind of like the directory or the index
that I talked about before.
I think I actually covered most of this already.
But one thing I wanted to touch on
was this idea of multiplexing, which
is an idea that kind of comes from a libv2b, basically.
So there's basically--
it's kind of like function overriding,
but like on the network level.
So if I want, for example, to request some information,
I shouldn't have to care about how that information is stored
or how it's fetched.
I should just be able to ask it, ask for it,
and have some guarantee about how it gets to me.
So kind of the multiplexing in this case
is that we have keys that can be stored on a smart contract
or keys that can be stored in a database.
And when you look up, you kind of do
that look up of both the smart contract
and the database in parallel.
And on the application level, you don't really care
about where that key is stored.
You can just use it.
And this also allows for the addition
of other types of data storage for distributing the keys,
one of which we use in our demo, which is kind of interesting.
So, often privacy.
So this is kind of the last step in the easy lifecycle.
So this is like after everything is generated and distributed,
we can just enjoy the benefits of everything
that the OpenB2b library offers.
So on a key space class, there is four function types
that are pretty much everything I'm going to use.
So you have an encrypt, which takes a message,
a plain text message, and the address
that you're going to send that encrypted message to.
Decrypt, which takes it, encrypted message,
and the from address so you can verify
that it was sent by the address you claim to send it.
And yeah, you can just get the decrypted message
that's meant for you.
And then we also, in isolation, provide a sign
